title: Safety Framework
meta_description: A framework for classifying how effectively safety has been designed into a device. Rate devices from 0 (no protection) to 5 (inherently safe).
og_description: A framework for classifying how effectively safety has been designed into a device. Like IP ratings, but for safety.
subtitle: A framework for classifying how effectively safety has been designed into a device.
intro_p1: How safe is a device, really? And how much does it depend on the person using it? This framework builds on the Hierarchy of Controls to give a clear answer. Think of it like IP ratings, but for how well a device protects its users.
intro_p2: Take the Petzl GriGri, a climbing device designed to grip the rope automatically when a climber falls. Many assume it will lock automatically, but catastrophic failures can occur when operators overestimate a device's safety level.
how_to_use: Rate the device based on its primary hazard under normal operating conditions. Focus on what the device does to protect the operator, not edge cases or deliberate tampering.
level_0_description: The device offers no protective features. The hazard is fully exposed and no skill or technique can make it safe.
level_0_example_1: A vintage bench grinder with no wheel guards, no eye shields, and no spark arrestors. The spinning abrasive wheel is fully exposed during operation.
level_0_example_2: An open fire pit. The flames and heat are exposed during use.
level_1_description: The device provides no engineering controls to help the operator. Safety relies entirely on user skill, procedures and PPE.
level_1_example_1: A basic chainsaw. Safety depends entirely on operator technique, stance, and PPE (chaps, helmet, gloves).
level_1_example_2: A tube-style belay device. The device has no automatic braking. Safety depends entirely on the belayer maintaining proper grip and technique.
level_2_description: The device provides cues, markings or warnings to encourage correct behaviour, but does not block unsafe use.
level_2_example_1: An extension ladder with angle indicators, "this side up" labels, and anti-slip feet. These cues guide correct setup, but nothing prevents the operator from ignoring them.
level_2_example_2: A circular saw with blade guard markings and a safety sticker. The warnings are visible, but nothing prevents the operator from removing the guard.
level_3_description: The device has built-in features that reduce risk automatically, but incorrect technique or accidental misuse can still result in harm.
level_3_example_1: A power drill with electronic brake, torque limiter, and insulated casing. These features reduce injury risk, but the operator can still slip or drill into something they shouldn't.
level_3_example_2: A car with seatbelts and airbags. The safety systems help significantly in a crash, but reckless driving can still cause serious harm.
level_3_example_3: An assisted-braking belay device, whether passive or active. The device helps catch a fall automatically, but incorrect technique can still cause the rope to slip through.
level_4_description: The device forces a safe state that cannot be overridden by the operator. No amount of incorrect technique, inattention, or misuse can bypass the protection during normal operation.
level_4_example_1: A microwave oven with redundant door interlocks. The magnetron physically cannot energise unless all switches confirm the door is sealed. The operator cannot run the microwave with the door open.
level_4_example_2: A lift with door interlocks and slack-rope brakes. The car cannot move unless the doors are closed, and it will stop automatically if the cable fails.
level_4_example_3: A climbing gym auto-belay. The device automatically takes up slack and arrests falls mechanically. The climber cannot override the braking system during normal use.
level_5_description: The danger is designed out entirely. The device simply cannot cause serious harm through normal use.
level_5_example_1: A plastic letter opener instead of a metal blade. It can open envelopes but cannot cut skin.
level_5_example_2: A battery-powered desk fan instead of a mains-powered one. The low voltage cannot deliver a dangerous shock.
table_level_1: No engineering controls. Safety depends on the operator.
table_level_2: Cues and warnings, but no enforcement.
table_level_3: Automatic protection, but incorrect technique or misuse can still cause harm.
table_level_4: Enforced safe state. Cannot be overridden by operator.
table_level_5: Hazard designed out. Cannot cause serious harm.
